Title: Craft work: Understanding the relationship between identity and work in the context of the future of work

The CRAFTWORK project proposes a multi-methodological, pan-European study to investigate the intricate relationship between identity and work in the context of the future of work. Focusing on the lived experiences, cultures, and practices of neo-craft workers across various sectors in the European Union, this project seeks to develop a new interpretative framework for understanding the complex dynamics between identity and work. By exploring subjectivities, pathways to work, class location perception, cultural conceptions of social status, urban-rural distribution, and the role of social media, this research aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the ways in which neo-craft workers navigate and make sense of their work in the face of an uncertain future. 

The project's innovative approach combines digital methods with qualitative research, marking a significant departure from traditional studies on work and identity. By doing so, CRAFTWORK will provide the first comprehensive inquiry into 'neo-craft' work in the EU, rethinking interpretative categories for the study of identity and work. Ultimately, this project will contribute to critical studies of new forms of work, addressing the pressing societal challenges of the future of work.
